body_html:
@allaisandrea -- While this is largely the workaround I use in practice, I've also run into a validation constraint where throttle_secs > 0 😅 , which is generally not a problem but has proven annoying when trying to debug stuff that might take less than a second to evaluate (especially in cases where the timing differs across environments).

@bhack I'm not sure I fully understand this, but -- is the idea now that there's going to be an eval kicked off after a checkpoint is saved? So you'd be able to control it with just save_checkpoint_steps?
body_text:
@allaisandrea  -- While this is largely the workaround I use in practice, I've also run into a validation constraint where throttle_secs > 0 😅 , which is generally not a problem but has proven annoying when trying to debug stuff that might take less than a second to evaluate (especially in cases where the timing differs across environments).
@bhack I'm not sure I fully understand this, but -- is the idea now that there's going to be an eval kicked off after a checkpoint is saved? So you'd be able to control it with just save_checkpoint_steps?
body:
@allaisandrea  -- While this is largely the workaround I use in practice, I've also run into a validation constraint where `throttle_secs > 0` :sweat_smile: , which is generally not a problem but has proven annoying when trying to debug stuff that might take less than a second to evaluate (especially in cases where the timing differs across environments).

@bhack I'm not sure I fully understand this, but -- is the idea now that there's going to be an eval kicked off after a checkpoint is saved? So you'd be able to control it with just `save_checkpoint_steps`?
